titleStmt.title: Animadversions upon the Armies Remonstrance, delivered to the House of Commons, Monday, 20. November, 1648. In vindication of the Parliaments treaty with the King in the Isle of Wight.

notesStmt.note: A reply to: A remonstrance of His Excellency Thomas Lord Fairfax, Lord General of the Parliaments forces. And of the generall councell of officers held at St Albans the 16. of November, 1648.
Annotation on Thomason copy: "1649". The 8 has been crossed out and the date altered to 1649.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: ANIMADVERSIONS UPON THE ARMIES REMONSTRANCE, DELIVERED To the HOUSE of COMMONS, Monday, 20. November, 1648.
In vindication of the PARLIAMENTS TREATY with the KING in the JÅ¿le of Wight.

q.l: Turpe eÅ¿t Doctori cum culpa redarguit ipÅ¿um.
In tabulam Syllae dicunt ejus diÅ¿cipuli tres.

div.p: LONDON. Printed in the Year, 1648.

div.head: ANIMADVERSIONS UPON The ARMIES REMONTRANCE, DELIVERED To the HouÅ¿e of Commons, Monday, 20. November, 1648.
div.p: ABout May 1647. The 2 HouÅ¿es in a full and free Parliament took into conÅ¿ideration how to eaÅ¿e the people of their Taxes; in order whereto they ordained the Disbanding this Army (6000 or 7000 onely excepted to Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿e InÅ¿urrections in England, and the reÅ¿t to be Å¿ent to the relief of Ireland) 200000l. was provided for this worke, for the reÅ¿t of their Arreares they were to have unqueÅ¿tionable Å¿ecurity. Lieutenant Generall Cromwell Å¿ubtilly encouraged the HouÅ¿e of Commons to this reÅ¿olution, with intent rather to diÅ¿content, then disband the Army (which hates nothing more then diÅ¿banding, and returning to their old Trades) and then to make uÅ¿e of their diÅ¿contents againÅ¿t the Authours of this counÅ¿ell, being men of different principles and intereÅ¿ts from himÅ¿elf.

To carry on which deÅ¿igne, he, and his Son Ireton upon the 4 & 5 of June, by their Agitators, (men whoÅ¿e publique Å¿pirits they abuÅ¿ed for private ends,Book of Decl. p. 22. Solem: Engagement. and at laÅ¿t caÅ¿t them off) cauÅ¿ed the Army to enter into an Engagement (in oppoÅ¿ition to the Å¿aid Ordinance) not to diÅ¿band, nor to divide.

June 23. at Saint Albans, the Army Declared,Book of Decl. p. 39. That their reÅ¿pects to the Peoples Safety inforced them to admit of no longer delaies
then foure or five daies, wherein the HouÅ¿e Å¿hould give aÅ¿Å¿urance to them and the People of a Å¿afe and Å¿peedy proceeding to Å¿ettle the Armies, Pag. 67. and the Kingdomes rights, and freedomes.

After this, Cromwell plotted the Å¿ecuring of Oxford, and the Å¿urprizing of the Kings PerÅ¿on by his inÅ¿trument Joyce: and when Joyce told him, he had the King in his power, Then (quoth Cromwell) I have the Parliament in my pocket.

In farther proÅ¿ecution of which deÅ¿igne, to pull downe their oppoÅ¿ite Faction: They cauÅ¿ed an Impeachment in the name of Sir Tho: Fairfax and the Army, Putney Projects, p. 8.9. (in generall Tearmes onely, for the particular matters of their Charge was to Å¿eeke, after they had in generall charged them) to be Å¿ent to the HouÅ¿e of Commons againÅ¿t eleven of their Members for Å¿ome things done in the HouÅ¿e, as That by their power they cauÅ¿ed the Ordinance for DiÅ¿banding the Army to paÅ¿Å¿e, &c. and for Å¿ome things done out of the HouÅ¿e, which had been formerly examined and cleared by the HouÅ¿e: As CorreÅ¿ponding with the King, &c. In the 2, 3, & 4. Article of which Charge, they profeÅ¿Å¿e themÅ¿elves diÅ¿obliged and diÅ¿couraged from any farther Engagement in the Parliaments Service. And indeed, they have Å¿ince carried themÅ¿elves as if they were diÅ¿obliged: for,

1. They demanded the HouÅ¿e to Å¿uspend the Å¿aid 11 Members from Å¿itting: Whereupon, the HouÅ¿e voted, 25. June. That by the Lawes of the Land no Judgment for their Å¿uspention could be given upon that generall Charge, before particulars produced, and proofs made: the Army thereupon, threatned to march up to WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter, unleÅ¿Å¿e they were Å¿uspended: whereby they were enforced to forbeare the HouÅ¿e.

2. They courted the people by undertaking to Å¿ettle Peace, to eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h the Kings intereÅ¿t, and all other juÅ¿t intereÅ¿ts: and invited the People to make AddreÅ¿Å¿es to the Army by Petitions againÅ¿t their grievances: to which they gave AnÅ¿wer, That, This and This is the Å¿enÅ¿e of the Army: The Declar. againÅ¿t the Army as Enemies to the State unvoted, Put. Pro. p. 9. Å¿ee RepreÅ¿: June 4.5. B. of Decl. p. 33, 34. as if their Å¿enÅ¿e were the Å¿upreame Law.
3. They compell the Parliament to unvote Å¿ome of their Votes, and afterwards reproach them for their inconÅ¿tancy in their Printed Papers.

4. They turne the Councel of Warre, into a Councel of State; and there debate and reÅ¿olve all Publique Affaires, as if they were
another Parliament, judging of all Publique IntereÅ¿ts, and Safety of the Kingdome; The Prerogative of the King: Fundamentals of Parliament: and Lawes of the Land: as if they would (legem dare) impoÅ¿e Lawes upon the Land: for (I am Å¿ure) they are not learned enough (legem dicere) to expound the Law.
5. They march like Conquerours through London, Put: Proj: p. 9. fright away many Members of Parliament, throw downe their defenÅ¿ive Works, Å¿et Guards upon the HouÅ¿es, &c.

6. They obey Ordinances of Parliament but at their owne diÅ¿cretion. The HouÅ¿es Voted the Disbanding of Supernumeraries: They colluÅ¿orily Disband Å¿ome in one place, and take them in againe in another: and (by way of Bargaine, as it were) they lately demanded 3000. of them to be added to the eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed Army which is already above 27000 men, and hath an eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed pay of 60000l. Å¿terling a Month; a far greater pay, and better paid then any Army of ChriÅ¿tendome of the like number hath: and yet they have often demanded an addition of 20000l. a Month more, and did demand a weekly Tax for Fire and Candle, and doe take free quarter. And though the HouÅ¿es have voted the diÅ¿garriÅ¿oning of divers inland GarriÅ¿ons for eaÅ¿e of the People, yet they are not obeyed: for now (as Putney Projects Å¿ay, pag. 9.) The Parliament trembles at the Å¿haking of their rod, and every of their deÅ¿ires to the HouÅ¿e is a Mandamus; both King and Parliament being Å¿ubjected to their beck.

7. And laÅ¿tly, though they Declare, June 14. 1647. That they continued in Armes, in Judgement and RighteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, for the ends Å¿pecified in the Parliaments Declarations: and were not ignorant, The Parliament Å¿undry times declared the intent of their War to be for removing evill CounÅ¿ellors from the King, 1 Part Exact Col: p. 118. 632 and for preÅ¿ervation and defence of His PerÅ¿on, Crowne, and Dignity, &c. Yet having the KING in their cuÅ¿tody at Hampton-Court, they opened a free way of acceÅ¿Å¿e to him for many the moÅ¿t malignant of his party: As Mr. John AÅ¿hburnham, The Machiavilian CromwelliÅ¿ts. whom Cromwell (whoÅ¿e pulÅ¿e about this time beat a Lordly pace, as one of their owne pen-men Å¿aith) and Ireton Å¿ent for out of France. Col: William Leg, whom they cauÅ¿ed to be admitted of the Kings Bed-chamber. Sir Will: Ford, a PapiÅ¿t, Iretons Brother-in-law, and Major BoÅ¿well, both of them reÅ¿ident for the King in the Army to corrupt the Souldiery, and
many more, by whoÅ¿e mediation they entertained correÅ¿pondence with the King himÅ¿elfe, and had their Å¿et-dayes of writing Letters into France and Holland concerning an Accommodation. And the better to mould the Souldiery to their deÅ¿ignes, they inrolled many Cavaliers in the Army, who cryed out at Ware, Charge againÅ¿t 11 Members. Book of Decla. page 112. For the King and Sir Thomas: And yet they called M. Hollis his correÅ¿pondence with the King, A breach of truÅ¿t, a breach of his Oath, taken in June 1643. a breach of the Parliaments Ordinance in October 1643. and no leÅ¿Å¿e then TreaÅ¿on.

Book of Declaration. pag. 112At this time Ireton framed the PropoÅ¿als at Colebrook, which, as they Å¿ay, contained the particulars of their deÅ¿ires in order to the clearing and Å¿ecuring the Rights and Liberties of the people, and Å¿etling a laÅ¿ting Peace. By theÅ¿e PropoÅ¿alls the foundations of the peoples Freedome were undermined, and the Kings IntereÅ¿t Å¿upported; as Putney projects, pag. 13. Å¿aid, where it is believed they paÅ¿Å¿ed ãâã a Generall Councell. And it is there affirmed, that they paÅ¿Å¿ed the Kings file, who moved for a PerÅ¿onall Treaty upon them. Ireton, in a private Conference, having promiÅ¿ed the King a Copy of them, which was Å¿ent by Major Huntington, and returned with the Kings croÅ¿Å¿es and Å¿cratches upon them with His own pen.page 14. At laÅ¿t Sir John Berkley, and AÅ¿hburnham, brought the Kings AnÅ¿wer to them at Colebrook, AuguÅ¿t 1. and the PropoÅ¿alls bear date AuguÅ¿t 2. and the PropoÅ¿alls were altered in five or Å¿ix Particulars, nearly relating to the Kings IntereÅ¿t.

But now let us collect Å¿ome few Å¿hort ObÅ¿ervations out of the Papers, and the Å¿aid PropoÅ¿alls of the Army; that by comparing them with the preÅ¿ent PropoÅ¿itions Å¿ent to the IÅ¿le of Wight by the Parliament, it may appear whether the Army that hath no Authority, or the Parliament that hath Authority, to Treat with the King, have beÅ¿t provided for a Å¿afe and well-grounded Peace, with preÅ¿ervation of our Religion, Lawes and Liberties.

Book of Declaration. pag. 45.In the RepreÅ¿entation of the Army, June 14. 1647. this is Å¿et downe as the 8. propoÅ¿all for Peace: That (publique JuÅ¿tice being firÅ¿t Å¿atisfied by Å¿ome few examples to poÅ¿terity, out of the worÅ¿t excepted perÅ¿ons, and other Delinquents, having made their CompoÅ¿itions) Å¿ome courÅ¿e may be taken for a generall Act of Oblivion;
whereby the Å¿eeds of Warre, &c. may be the better taken away.

1. ObÅ¿ervation. The wiÅ¿dome of Parliament thought it not fit to disparage their righteous cauÅ¿e by propounding an Act of Oblivion; but when the King freely offered it, and made it a propoÅ¿all on his part, they accepted it, reÅ¿erving a power to themÅ¿elves to adde what exceptions and limitations to it, the two HouÅ¿es Å¿hould think fit.

In the RemonÅ¿trance of the Army preÅ¿ented to the Parliaments CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners at S. Albans, June 23. 1647.page 64. They declare their principles to be moÅ¿t cleerly for a generall Right, and juÅ¿t freedome to all: and therefore declare particularly, That they deÅ¿ire the Å¿ame for the King and others of His party, (Å¿o farre as can conÅ¿iÅ¿t with common Right and Freedome, and the Å¿ecurity of the Å¿ame for the future.) And they doe clearly profeÅ¿Å¿e they doe not Å¿ee how there can be any peace to the Kingdome firme and laÅ¿ting, without a due conÅ¿ideration of, and proviÅ¿ion for the Rights, quiet and immunity of His MajeÅ¿ties Royall Family, and his late partakers: and herein they think that tender and equitable dealing (as Å¿uppoÅ¿ing their cauÅ¿e had been ours) and a Å¿pirit of common love and juÅ¿tice, diffuÅ¿ing it Å¿elfe to the good and preÅ¿ervation of all, will make up the moÅ¿t glorious conqueÅ¿t over their hearts, to make them and the whole people of the Land laÅ¿ting friends.

2. ObÅ¿ervation. What more could the Parliament Å¿ay? PeruÅ¿e the PropoÅ¿itions Å¿ent to the IÅ¿le of Wight.
What more hath the Parliament done for the King and his party in their PerÅ¿onall Treaty with the King at the IÅ¿le of Wight, for a Å¿afe and well-grounded Peace, then here the Army prompts them to? Or how hath the King deÅ¿erved worÅ¿e of the Kingdome Å¿ince the Army hunted Him from Hampton-court into their PurÅ¿e-net at Carisbrooke-CaÅ¿tle, where He hath been watched, and kept in Å¿o Å¿trict and limited a condition, that He could neither act nor negotiate any thing? But (The Armies Scout Å¿aith) the Grandees of the Armies Faction are exaÅ¿perated againÅ¿t him for rejecting their offers laÅ¿t yeare, and his adherence to the ScottiÅ¿h intereÅ¿t: and therefore at the latter end of his foule Å¿heet the Scout hath this DiÅ¿tich,
ã1 page duplicateã
ã1 page duplicateã
Oh Charles, old Nol (thy terrour) now draws nigh,
If thou wilt Å¿ave thy necke, haÅ¿t, haÅ¿t, to flie.

Book of Decl. p. 75.In a Letter from Sir Thomas Fairfax to both HouÅ¿es, giving an account of the tranÅ¿actions between His MajeÅ¿ty, and the Army, (bearing date, Reading, July 6. 1647.) He Å¿aith, We conceive that to avoid all harÅ¿hneÅ¿Å¿e, and to afford all kind uÅ¿age to His MajeÅ¿ties PerÅ¿on, in things conÅ¿iÅ¿ting with the peace and Å¿afety of the Kingdome; is the moÅ¿t ChriÅ¿tian, honourable and prudent way: and in all things (as the RepreÅ¿entation and RemonÅ¿trance of the Army doth expreÅ¿Å¿e) we thinke that tender, equitable, and moderate dealing, both towards His MajeÅ¿ty, His Royall Family, and late Party, (Å¿o farre as may Å¿tand with the Å¿afety of the Kingdome, and Å¿ecurity of our common Rights and Liberties) is the moÅ¿t hopefull courÅ¿e to take away the Å¿eeds of Warre, &c. and to procure a laÅ¿ting peace, and a Government in this distracted Nation.

3. ObÅ¿ervation. But the Army hath Å¿ince found New Lights: yet theÅ¿e plauÅ¿ible pretences of the Army to reÅ¿tore Peace and Government by Å¿etling the Kings, and all juÅ¿t Rights, kept the People hitherto quiet, and made them with hope and patience to beare Taxes to the Army and Free quarter, whereby many of their backs were broken, and all galled: untill they found the Army to lay by theÅ¿e principles, and to make uÅ¿e of the good opinion they had got onely by them, to Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿e and deÅ¿troy all that laboured for peace and eaÅ¿e of the people; both Petitioners and Members of Parliament to keep themÅ¿elves Å¿till in pay, and purÅ¿ue their owne profit, and preferment, then finding themÅ¿elves cheated, deÅ¿paire thruÅ¿t them raÅ¿hly into Armes in Wales, Kent, EÅ¿Å¿ex, &c. where their Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e was Å¿uitable to their diÅ¿cretion, whereof the Faction of the Army doe now take advantage to lay their owne baÅ¿tard at other mens dores, as if all this were done by deÅ¿igne of a Party in Parliament and City. But Peace and an Army are as inconÅ¿iÅ¿tent together as light and darkneÅ¿Å¿e.
In the PropoÅ¿als of the Army, 1 Aug. 1647. they propound,

14. That (things before propoÅ¿ed being provided for Å¿ecuring the Rights, Liberties, and Safety of the Kingdome.) His MajeÅ¿ties
PerÅ¿on, Queen, and Royall iÅ¿Å¿ue may be reÅ¿tored to a condition of Safety, Honour, and Freedome in this Nation, without diminution of their perÅ¿onall Rights, or farther limitation to the exerciÅ¿e of the Regall power, then according to the particulars aforegoing.

4. ObÅ¿ervation. You Å¿ee the City in their Engagement, and the Parliament borrowed from the Army, that phraÅ¿e they now Å¿o much cry out upon, of reÅ¿toring the King, with Honour, Freedome and Safety.

15. For CompoÅ¿itions, The Army propounds, That a leÅ¿Å¿er number out of the perÅ¿ons excepted in the two firÅ¿t Qualifications, (not exceeding five for the EngliÅ¿h) being nominated particularly by the Parl. who (together with the perÅ¿ons in the IriÅ¿h Rebellion included in the third Qualification) may be reÅ¿erved to the farther Judgement of the Parliament as they Å¿hall Å¿ee cauÅ¿e: all other perÅ¿ons may be admitted to CompoÅ¿ition. That the rates for all future CompoÅ¿itions may be leÅ¿Å¿ened, &c. and no compounder enjoyned to take the Nationall Covenant.

5. ObÅ¿erva. You Å¿ee the Army more remiÅ¿Å¿e in exacting JuÅ¿tice then the Parliament, who have excepted Å¿even EngliÅ¿h clearly out of mercy, which is more then to reÅ¿erve them unto farther JuÅ¿tice, as they Å¿hall Å¿ee cauÅ¿e: and all men to be enjoyned by Act of Parliament to take the Covenant.

The Army propounds,Putney Proj. pag. 14. That all that have been in hoÅ¿tility againÅ¿t the Parliament, be incapable of bearing Office of publique truÅ¿t, or power for five yeares. But it was added (after the great Officers intercourÅ¿e with the King) That the Councell of State Å¿hould be enabled to admit them to Å¿uch Offices before thoÅ¿e five yeares expired.

6. ObÅ¿ervation. The Parliament hath reÅ¿erved to themÅ¿elves the gifts of all Great Offices in England and Ireland for 20. yeares, and diÅ¿abled Delinquents in Armes to be Sheriffes, JuÅ¿tices of the Peace, &c.

pag. 15.The Army propounded, Only that the Coercive Power, and JuriÅ¿diction of BiÅ¿hops, extending to Civill PuniÅ¿hments upon any, may be aboliÅ¿hed and demanded, nothing for paÅ¿Å¿ing an Act for Å¿ale of BiÅ¿hops Lands; although at laÅ¿t they encouraged the Parliament to Å¿ell them. But according to their PropoÅ¿als for Peace, the King was firÅ¿t to be re-eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed with His Negative voice.
7. ObÅ¿ervation. The Parliament propounds the utter AboliÅ¿hing of EpiÅ¿copacy, and BiÅ¿hops for ever: and an Act for alienating their Lands for ever.
The Army propounded, The Militia Å¿hould be for ten yeares only, in the diÅ¿poÅ¿e of the Parliament, and afterwards, this preÅ¿ent King not to diÅ¿poÅ¿e thereof without conÅ¿ent of Parliament.

8. ObÅ¿ervation. The Parliament propounds the Militia of England and Ireland, by Land and Sea, with all Forts, CaÅ¿tles, GarriÅ¿ons, to be in the Parliament alone for twenty yeares, from 1 July, 1646. And after the Å¿aid twenty yeares, neither the King, His Heires, nor SucceÅ¿Å¿ors to diÅ¿poÅ¿e thereof without conÅ¿ent of Parliament, &c.

Putney Project pag. 43.TheÅ¿e PropoÅ¿als of the Army being obtruded at laÅ¿t, upon the HouÅ¿e, a conteÅ¿t grew, Whether they, or the PropoÅ¿itions formerly Å¿ent to New-CaÅ¿tle Å¿hould be Å¿ent to the King at Hampton-Court. At laÅ¿t it was concluded to Å¿end the PropoÅ¿itions of New-CaÅ¿tle, But the King knew, that neither the Grandees in Parlia. or Army, intended they Å¿hould be aÅ¿Å¿ented to, being inconÅ¿iÅ¿tent with their Independent intereÅ¿ts; but they were Å¿ent only to uÅ¿her in the Kings deÅ¿ire of a PerÅ¿onall Treaty upon the PropoÅ¿als of the Army: which the King had made known before hand Å¿hould be His AnÅ¿wer. And when His AnÅ¿wer was Voted in the HouÅ¿e of Commons to be a deniall, and debated hotly, whether any more AddreÅ¿Å¿es Å¿hould be made to the King; at laÅ¿t a Member of the HouÅ¿e produced a reaÅ¿on as Å¿harp and weighty, as Goliahs Å¿word. It is the Å¿enÅ¿e of the Army (quoth he) that a farther AddreÅ¿Å¿e be made to the King. And Ireton himÅ¿elf told them, he could not promiÅ¿e them the Armies aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance if they ceaÅ¿ed their
AddreÅ¿Å¿es to the King: whereupon, being bruited abroad, that the Army had compelled the Parliament to make farther AddreÅ¿Å¿es to the King, and to Å¿end part, or all of their PropoÅ¿als as the grounds of Peace: very many of the Army declared openly againÅ¿t it: and many Speeches in their Councell reflected upon Ireton, for abuÅ¿ing the Army therein. So their hopes in this policy vaniÅ¿hed, like the hopes of an AlchimiÅ¿t.

I could proceed much farther with theÅ¿e parallel ObÅ¿ervations; but I have little leaÅ¿ure, and peradventure Reader, thou haÅ¿t little money to lay out upon Books; and I deÅ¿ire to open thy eyes as good cheap as may be. But the Armies RemonÅ¿trance preÅ¿ented to the HouÅ¿e, 20 November, pag. 43. 44. Å¿aith, TheÅ¿e Compliances of their part were only Negative: what I have Å¿aid already doth Å¿ufficiently confute this excuÅ¿e. It farther Å¿aith, they complied with the King through example, to prevent others from Å¿trengthening themÅ¿elves that way: meaning M. Hollis, &c. which was examined by the Parliament, and he acquitted thereof; and though the Army (not reÅ¿ting in the Judgement of the Parliament, as by their own profeÅ¿Å¿ion they ought to doe) charged him again herewith in their Impeachment of the eleven Members: yet they never proceeded to prove it. See Putney Project. pag. 8.

You Å¿ee that Priviledges, and Commands of Parliament, nay their own promiÅ¿es are no more to the Grandees of the Army, (Å¿ince they declared, the Parliament had diÅ¿obliged them) then the PhiliÅ¿tines withes to SampÅ¿on. Did they not command the Commons by a Å¿et day to caÅ¿t out the Faction that overtopped them, to recall their Declaration againÅ¿t them; whereby in full and free Parliament they were declared Enemies? to provide them pay? to own them for their Army? Have they not contrary to the Parliaments Orders admitted Cavaliers to the King? made AddreÅ¿Å¿es to Him? Quartered round about London after the Parliament Commanded them to Quarter fourty miles off, which Order is Å¿till in force? Have they not promiÅ¿ed and engaged to acquieÅ¿ce in the Judgement of Parliament? Declaration 14 June 1647. And did they not a year Å¿ince, keep a day of Humiliation at WindÅ¿or to implore Gods mercy for their former inÅ¿olency to the Parliament, and promiÅ¿ing more obedience hereafter?
Have they not declared that it was proper for them to act onely in their owne Å¿pheare as Souldiers, and not to intermeddle with affaires of State, which concerne the Parliament? Why then doe they interrupt the Parliaments Treaty with the King in the IÅ¿le of Wight? Declaration 14 June 1647. Why did they 20. Novemb. 1648. Å¿end a peremptory RemonÅ¿trance to the Parliament, (inÅ¿tead of an humble Petition) charging them with weakneÅ¿Å¿e, inconÅ¿tancie, and breach of truÅ¿t in the Å¿ame Treaty, and magnifying their owne wiÅ¿dome and integrity above theirs; and that in Å¿uch MagiÅ¿teriall, and cenÅ¿orious language, as if the Tables were turned, and they were the Parliament, and the Two HouÅ¿es but a Councell of the Army. I will continue the method I have begun, and make Å¿ome few, Å¿udden ObÅ¿ervations upon this RemonÅ¿trance, as I have formerly done upon the Armies PropoÅ¿als: and leave the fuller anÅ¿wering thereof to Å¿ome better Pen, that hath more leiÅ¿ure and abilities then my Å¿elfe.
Objections in the RemonÅ¿trance, delivered 20. November, againÅ¿t the Parliament and Treaty.

RemonÅ¿trance, pag. 7, 8, 9.1. The Army Objects, the Votes of the HouÅ¿es for no more AddreÅ¿Å¿es to the King. Charging the HouÅ¿es with inconÅ¿tancy in retracting them: and thereby putting the people into an unÅ¿etled condition; and Å¿tirring them to Petition for a PerÅ¿onall Treaty, and at laÅ¿t to riÅ¿e in Armes for it, and alledgeth the HouÅ¿e was free at the paÅ¿Å¿ing thoÅ¿e Votes.

AnÅ¿w. 1. The Å¿aid Votes for no more AddreÅ¿Å¿es to the King; were contrived in private, betweene the Independent Grandees of the HouÅ¿es and Army: and then impoÅ¿ed upon the HouÅ¿e of Commons, after many of their Members were frighted away by blanke Impeachments in the HouÅ¿e, and by the Armies hovering about the Towne to back their own party,Putney Proj. pag. 43. and Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿e all men of contrary judgment. Not were the debates in the HouÅ¿e free, Ireton leading the Van in the debate, and telling them the Å¿ence of the Army (which uÅ¿ually leadeth every reaÅ¿on captive.) That now it was expected they Å¿hould Å¿ettle the Kingdome without the King, and not diÅ¿Å¿ert thoÅ¿e valiant men who had engaged for them beyond all hopes of Retreat, and would never forÅ¿ake the Parliament,
unleÅ¿Å¿e the Parliament forÅ¿ooke them firÅ¿t. And during the whole debate, the Armies party often taunted them that Å¿pake for farther AddreÅ¿Å¿es, calling them the Kings party in the Commons HouÅ¿e: and when they were ready for the queÅ¿tion, Cromwell brought up the Reare: Å¿aying, It was now expected the Parliament Å¿hould governe the Kingdome by their owne power and reÅ¿olutions, and not teach the people to expect Å¿afety from a man whoÅ¿e heart God had hardned. That thoÅ¿e men that had hitherto defended the Parliament, would defend them herein againÅ¿t all oppoÅ¿ition, Teach them not by neglecting the Kingdomes Å¿afety, to thinke themÅ¿elves betrayed: and left to the malice of an irreconcilable enemy, whom they have Å¿ubdued for your Å¿ake, and are like to find his future Government inÅ¿upportable, and full of revenge: leÅ¿t deÅ¿paire teach them to Å¿eeke their Å¿afety by other means then by adhering to you: and how deÅ¿tructive Å¿uch a reÅ¿olution in them will be to you all, I tremble to think, and leave you to judge. With which words he concluded, laying his hand upon his Sword, and putting on as Å¿terne a vizard of terror, as Å¿uch a face could fall into. You Å¿ee now with what bridle they turne and rule the HouÅ¿e, they can deliver the Å¿ence of the Army for AddreÅ¿Å¿es to the King, and againÅ¿t AddreÅ¿Å¿es; and with the winde of their Breaths, make the Weather-cock Å¿it which way they pleaÅ¿e: Not long after, in a thin HouÅ¿e, and at an unÅ¿eaÅ¿onable time of the day, it was moved, that a letter might be forthwith Å¿ent to the Generall, to Å¿end a party of Foot to GarriÅ¿on White-hall, and a party of HorÅ¿e to GarriÅ¿on the Mewes. The Lords concurrence not deÅ¿ired, and the letters immediately Å¿ent. But before this Vote paÅ¿Å¿ed, divers Forces were upon their march neere the town, and came to White-Hall next morning by 8. of the clock: for this Å¿ubÅ¿equent Vote did but colour and ratifie what the Army had formerly reÅ¿olved and put in execution. As Å¿oon as White-Hall was GarriÅ¿oned, that very day the Army Å¿ent a Declaration to the Commons, thanking them for their foure Votes againÅ¿t the King, and promiÅ¿ing to live and die with them in defence of them againÅ¿t all opponents. The Lords had debated hotly upon theÅ¿e Votes, inÅ¿omuch that it was 10. Lords to 10. The ballance inclining to neither Å¿ide, untill the unexpected GarriÅ¿oning
of White-Hall and the Mewes, and the Å¿aid Declaration or Engagement of the Army to the Commons turned the Å¿cales; and then NeceÅ¿Å¿ity (which neither knowes Law nor ReaÅ¿on) prevailed with them to paÅ¿Å¿e thoÅ¿e Votes three or forre dayes after, (that both Lords and Commons might draw in one equall yoak) the Army was pleaÅ¿ed to give them thanks alÅ¿o. TheÅ¿e foure Votes troubled the whole Kingdome, and filled mens mindes with Å¿uÅ¿pition, what new forme of Government the Authors of them would Å¿et up: and every mans mind preÅ¿aged theÅ¿e Grandees deÅ¿ired a new War, for upholding this Army, and their owne power, and to colour their raiÅ¿ing money, which they Å¿hare amongÅ¿t the Army and themÅ¿elves: and every man now laid the project of a new Warre at their doore, and it now appeared to every intelligent man, that their Impeachings of divers Members and Citizens for endeavouring a new Warre, (when they did but arme in their owne defence againÅ¿t the printed threats and menaces of the Army then upon their march towards London) was done by way of prevention onely: it having alwayes been an impudent policy of this Faction, To accuÅ¿e other men of thoÅ¿e crimes which themÅ¿elves onely had or would commit, and thereby to amuÅ¿e the people. But Å¿uppoÅ¿e the HouÅ¿es had been free at the paÅ¿Å¿ing the Å¿aid four Votes? Sapientis eÅ¿t mutare conÅ¿ilium, WiÅ¿e men muÅ¿t vary their counÅ¿els according to emergent occaÅ¿ions and circumÅ¿tances. The heavy Taxes and Free-quarter of the Army, with their inÅ¿olent carriage in mens houÅ¿es, giving out, They had conquered the Kingdome: their turning their Councel of War into a Court of Judicature, contrary to the Lawes of the Land, but principally their courting and cheating all the intereÅ¿ts of the Kingdome: their committing open adultery with the Kings IntereÅ¿t in order to Peace, and then caÅ¿ting it off upon private diÅ¿like, (as hath been already Å¿aid in the third ObÅ¿ervation) had enraged the whole Kingdome (even the beÅ¿t affected, and moÅ¿t conÅ¿tant) and made them deÅ¿irous of a PerÅ¿onall Treaty, (to which the Armies PropoÅ¿als gave the riÅ¿e) and of their disbanding: Without which, either there can be no Peace, or we Å¿hall Å¿uffer all the diÅ¿commodities
of Warre in time of Peace; Mars is a good Souldier but a bad MagiÅ¿trate; and a military Government the worÅ¿t of all others. As for the Declaration of Parliament againÅ¿t the King, Å¿hewing the grounds and reaÅ¿ons of the Å¿aid 4 Votes, all men know they gave no Å¿atisfaction to the people; and the weakneÅ¿Å¿e, falÅ¿hood, and abÅ¿urdities thereof hath been Å¿ufficiently laid open by many good pens.

Object. 2.Rem. p. 12, 13. That the Lords cloÅ¿ed readily with all the deÅ¿ires of the City Malignants, the Prince, and all the Parliaments Enemies, going before the Commons, and haling them after: and when at any thing towards the Treaty, the Commons made Å¿ome Å¿ticke, then clamorous Petitions from the City came thicke, with menaces inÅ¿inuated; debauched Reformadoes, desperate Cavaliers, faithfull Members driven out of Towne, &c. We conceive at this time the Judgment of Parliament was not with due and former freedome.

AnÅ¿wer 2. Here is a cauÅ¿leÅ¿Å¿e quarrell picked againÅ¿t the Lords, City, and Reformadoes; againÅ¿t the Lords, in order to lay by the King, againÅ¿t the City for being rich, and againÅ¿t the Reformadoes for being valiant, and no Hypocrites; the Petitioners for a Treaty for Peace never petitioned againÅ¿t the Fundamentall Government, and Lawes of the Land; nor againÅ¿t any known Priviledge of Parliament; nor in a peremptory manner, as the Petitioners, 11. Septemb. (countenanced in this RemonÅ¿t: p. 69.) did; nor did they Å¿end any inÅ¿olent RemonÅ¿trance to the HouÅ¿e, or uÅ¿e any menaces either inÅ¿inuated, or open; as the Army and their Adherents uÅ¿ually doe; nor were any faithful Members driven out of Towne; politique Fugitives have heretofore run away to the Army, and may doe againe upon pretended feares, to carry on their deÅ¿igne; and to colour the open violence, and Å¿ecret conÅ¿piracies they have uÅ¿ed, or meane to uÅ¿e againÅ¿t the lives of their Opponents. I wiÅ¿h theÅ¿e titular Godly, faithfull, HoneÅ¿t men, would as much abhorre the profitable Art of Lying and Slandering, as they doe the unprofitable Vice of Swearing and CurÅ¿ing: But this is to take a SchiÅ¿matick out of a SchiÅ¿matick, an AntimonarchiÅ¿t out of an AntimonarchiÅ¿t, and an Independent out of an Independent
it is to take his definition from him, as much as to deny a man to be animal viÅ¿ibile: in this objection I can more clearly foreÅ¿ee a Å¿econd force comming from the Army upon the HouÅ¿es, then Lilly (with all his fantaÅ¿ticall Å¿chemes) can prognoÅ¿ticate faire or foule weather, good or bad luck. Were the HouÅ¿es free when Sir Tho: Fairfax threatned to make Å¿ome of the Members PriÅ¿oners of Warre, and trie them by a Councell of Warre, onely for voting, I, and No; according to their conÅ¿ciences? when he marched in hoÅ¿tile manner againÅ¿t the HouÅ¿es and City, and really frighted away many honeÅ¿t Members? when he Å¿et his owne Guards upon the HouÅ¿es? when the Armies faction in the HouÅ¿e threatned the diÅ¿Å¿enting Members with the Army, and the longeÅ¿t Å¿word? if they were free then, they were not free during the agitation of this PerÅ¿onall Treaty.

But let us now examine the principall PropoÅ¿itions for Å¿etling the Kingdomes peace and Å¿afety, as they are contained in this perplexed, confuÅ¿ed, long-winded RemonÅ¿trance, and then open your underÅ¿tanding with Å¿ome ObÅ¿ervations upon them.

The chief PropoÅ¿itions of this RemonÅ¿trance are the Å¿ame in effect with thoÅ¿e PropoÅ¿itions Å¿et on foot in the Army by the Levelling party there, in a printed Book, called, [The Agreement of the People] which were diÅ¿avowed by the Generall in his Letter to the HouÅ¿e: and Å¿ome of the Levellers were condemned by a Councell of Warre, as Å¿editious and mutinous PerÅ¿ons for promoting them.

The firÅ¿t PropoÅ¿ition is, That the HouÅ¿e would forbeare any farther proceeding in the Treaty with the King, and to returne to the Votes [for no more AddreÅ¿Å¿es to Him] and to Å¿ettle the Kingdome without and against Him, upon Å¿uch grounds as the Å¿aid RemonÅ¿trance doth lay downe.

1. ObÅ¿ervation. After the HouÅ¿es are ingaged paÅ¿t all retreat, and the eyes of all ChriÅ¿tendome upon them, they enjoyne them to breake off the Treaty contrary to their faith and honour engaged: when the Treaty is Å¿o neare a concluÅ¿ion
that we Å¿hall Å¿uddenly receive the Kings ConceÅ¿Å¿ions? or have a juÅ¿t ground to Å¿ettle the Kingdome againÅ¿t Him without breach of faith. Let us now Å¿ee what foundations of Å¿etlement theÅ¿e new States-men lay downe.
2. PropoÅ¿ition. That the King may be brought to JuÅ¿tice for the TreaÅ¿on, Bloud and miÅ¿chief he is guilty of.

2. ObÅ¿er. The Parliament in their Å¿everall Declarations, and in their CommiÅ¿Å¿ions to their Generalls alwaies accuÅ¿ed the Kings evil CounÅ¿ellours of theÅ¿e crimes, and not the King; following therein the civility and policy of our Lawes; and declared Warre onely againÅ¿t them, not againÅ¿t Him; knowing it had been High TreaÅ¿on by all our Lawes to warre againÅ¿t His PerÅ¿on, Stat. 25 Edw. 3. And I challenge all the Antimonarchicall tribe to Å¿hew me one Law or Stat. to the contrary, or to Å¿hew me any one preÅ¿ident in the Scriptures of any King of Juda or IÅ¿rael depoÅ¿ed or put to death upon Triall by his people for miÅ¿government, or any King of England Å¿o dealt with Å¿ince the ConqueÅ¿t. Rich. 2. Ed. 2. & Hen. 6. were articled againÅ¿t and DepoÅ¿ed, or forced to DepoÅ¿e themÅ¿elves in Parliament, but thoÅ¿e Parliaments were not free Parliaments (being packed and overawed by ambitious Princes of the bloud, with Souldiers) and therefore this cannot be imputed to the People. And the King, being by our Lawes, Å¿upreame Governour in all CauÅ¿es and over all PerÅ¿ons; hath no Superiour who can call Him to account; otherwiÅ¿e you muÅ¿t proceed in infinitum: If you will Å¿ay the People or their RepreÅ¿entative Å¿hall call Him to account, who Å¿hall call them to account? Parliaments (for ought I Å¿ee) being as Å¿ubject to corruption as Kings. BeÅ¿ides, you open a wide gap for any ambitious Prince of the bloud to make himÅ¿elf popular by Å¿candalizing the preÅ¿ent Government, (as AbÅ¿olom did) and Å¿o to Å¿tirre up the People or Parliament againÅ¿t the King to make way to the Crowne for himÅ¿elfe: and involve the Kingdome in frequent and lingering Civill Wars.

3. Prop: That the Prince and Duke of Yorke may be Å¿ummoned
to render themÅ¿elves, &c. if they doe not, that then they may be declared incapable of Government, &c. and as Enemies and Traytors to die without mercy if afterwards found in this Kingdome: if they render themÅ¿elves, the Prince for his Capitall Delinquency to be proceeded againÅ¿t in juÅ¿tice. And the Duke as he Å¿hall give Å¿atiÅ¿faction, &c.

3. ObÅ¿erv. This is to lay by the King and His PoÅ¿terity, contrary to many Declarations and Engagements of the Parliament, and to enforce the Prince to caÅ¿t himÅ¿elfe into the Armes of the French, or Å¿ome other his Allies, PapiÅ¿ts, or others for Å¿uccour upon Å¿uch tearmes of diÅ¿advantage as they (working upon his neceÅ¿Å¿ity) Å¿hall put upon him, to the prejudice of theÅ¿e Realmes, his owne Religion, in his Match, or otherwiÅ¿e; and to compell him to bring an InvaÅ¿ion upon the Land, to aÅ¿Å¿ert his owne and the common CauÅ¿e of Kings, controverted in this example; and Å¿o turn our EpiÅ¿copall warre, into a Monarchicall warre; which will draw a confluence of all the looÅ¿e Souldiery of ChriÅ¿tendome to Å¿eek imployment here, and bring the calamities of Germany upon us.
4. Prop: That a period be Å¿et to this Parliament, &c.

4. ObÅ¿erv: I wiÅ¿h a period, Å¿o as this pragmaticall Army be firÅ¿t Disbanded, otherwiÅ¿e they acknowledging no King, and their MaÅ¿ters the Parliament being diÅ¿Å¿olved, the Kingdome will either be left under the government of the Army, or they will over-power all Elections, and Å¿et up a Mock-Parliament of their owne creation, whoÅ¿e Authority Å¿hall depend upon their Sword, and then the Å¿aid Parliament Å¿hall Å¿et the Å¿tamp of their Authority upon the Army, and between both, the Kingdome be Å¿awed in pieces.
5. Prop: That no King be hereafter admitted but upon the Election of the People; by their RepreÅ¿entatives.

5. AnÅ¿wer. They will firÅ¿t have a Parliament of their owne
making, as aforeÅ¿aid, and then this Parliament Å¿hall have a Conge d'eÅ¿tlier, or leave to chuÅ¿e a King of the Armies nominating: whether they will vouchÅ¿afe to abuÅ¿e the infancy of the Duke of GlouceÅ¿ter, & make him their property until they have had time to Å¿ettle their Utopian Government, to root out all Opponents, to fill all Places of power and profit with their owne Creatures, to breake the Peoples Å¿pirits with a cuÅ¿tomary Bondage, to diÅ¿-arme and impoveriÅ¿h them, and reduce them to the heartleÅ¿Å¿e condition of French PeaÅ¿ants; to Å¿ettle forraign Leagues and CorreÅ¿pondencies, and then lay him to Å¿leep with his Fathers? Or whether they will Elect King Nol, for our Soveraigne? (whoÅ¿e NoÅ¿e is clad in Purple already) God knowes. But he that knowes any thing, knowes the danger of Elective Kingdoms, liable to Faction and Civill Warres amongÅ¿t Competitors upon the death of every King, let the miÅ¿erable examples of the German Empire, Poland, the old Roman Empire, and others witneÅ¿Å¿e.

6. Prop: TheÅ¿e things to be declared and provided by this Parliament, or by the Authority of the Commons therein, and all people to Å¿ubÅ¿cribe; nor any to be capable of any benefit by this Agreement who Å¿hall not conÅ¿ent and Å¿ubÅ¿cribe.

6. ObÅ¿erv: Here you Å¿ee the Lords and King (being 2 of the 3 EÅ¿tates, whereof our Parliaments are compounded by the fundamentall Lawes of the Land) Å¿trooke out, to the utter Å¿ubverÅ¿ion of Parliaments, and all men enjoyned to aÅ¿Å¿ent and Å¿ubÅ¿cribe to their owne wrong under a penalty, the conÅ¿equence whereof doth not yet appeare.
TheÅ¿e things (the RemonÅ¿trance Å¿aith) are of vaÅ¿t concernment to all publique IntereÅ¿t, not onely in this Kingdome, but neighbour Nations.

7. ObÅ¿erv: Whether this be Å¿poken to Scotland and Ireland onely, or to all neighbour Nations? as if theÅ¿e men had Å¿ome correÅ¿pondencies in their Dominions, to make this Antimonarchicall, popular diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, infective and diffuÅ¿ive
to them, thereby to divert them by Wars at home to look over upon us, God knowes: but it is very likely to Å¿tir up the jealouÅ¿ies of Forraign Princes, to quench the fire in their neighbours houÅ¿e, leÅ¿t the flame catch hold of their own.

1 ConÅ¿equence of the Å¿aid PropoÅ¿itions.TheÅ¿e PropoÅ¿itions tend to the utter Å¿ubverÅ¿ion of all the Fundamentall Government, and Lawes of this Land, and the deÅ¿truction of Parliaments, and will bring Å¿uch an Anarchy and confuÅ¿ion upon us, as will continue a War in our Bowels, during the life of this King, and His PoÅ¿terity; whereby we Å¿hall be enforced to keep up and augment this Army, and to entaile the Commands and Offices therein, upon the Grandees of the Army, their Sonnes and Adherents from Generation to Generation: and make a home Warre the only trade amongÅ¿t us.

2. ConÅ¿equence. The Army (by puutting the Parliament upon it, to be the Authors and Actors of theÅ¿e miÅ¿eries to their Country) will make them the common Å¿corne and hatred of all the world, and may then lay by the Parliament with applauÅ¿e of all men, glad of the revenge, and then Governe by the Sword. It is a Å¿ure rule in State, that when great men put their MiniÅ¿ters upon actions of publique hatred, they prepare them for deÅ¿truction.

3. ConÅ¿ideration. The Parliaments Declarations, the Laws of the Land, the Oaths of Allegeance, and Supremacy, and our Nationall Covenant do all cry out to the Parliament to oppoÅ¿e theÅ¿e deÅ¿troying PropoÅ¿itions.

The Declaration 26 May 1642. Å¿aith, Their endeavours have been for maintenance of the ProteÅ¿tant Religion, the Kings JuÅ¿t Prerogatives, The Lawes and Liberties of the Land, and Priviledges of Parliament, wherein they would perÅ¿iÅ¿t, though they Å¿hould periÅ¿h in the work.
1 Part. Exact Collections, pag. 618. 632.The like Declaration paÅ¿Å¿ed, June 2. 1642. upon the PropoÅ¿itions for Money and Plate.

42. Edw. 3. The Commons in Parliament Å¿ay, they cannot aÅ¿Å¿ent to any thing in Parliament to the DiÅ¿heriÅ¿on of the King and His Crown, whereto they are Sworne. The Petition of Right, 3 Caroli, The Commons in Parliament declare, That they neither meant, nor had power to hurt the Kings Prerogative, with infinite more Authorities, wherewith our Law-books are full.

By the Oathes of Allegeance and Supremacy (which every Member taketh before he Å¿its in Parliament) they are bound to defend and maintaine His MajeÅ¿ties Royall PerÅ¿on, with all the Prerogatives, Priviledges, and Preheminencies belonging, or annexed to the imperiall Crown.

By the Solemne League and Covenant we Å¿wear, with hands lifted up to God, To maintaine and defend the Kings PerÅ¿on and Authority, in the preÅ¿ervation of Religion, Lawes and Liberties; not to diminiÅ¿h his JuÅ¿t power and greatneÅ¿Å¿e, To defend the Priviledges of Parliament: And to continue all the dayes of their lives in this Covenant againÅ¿t all oppoÅ¿ition whatÅ¿oever. The ProteÅ¿tation is to the like effect.

But the Å¿aid RemonÅ¿trance, pag. 54, 55, 56, 57. Å¿aith, This is only a bare Covenant between party and party, wherein God is a witneÅ¿Å¿e only to avenge the breaker and violater thereof. But let this CaÅ¿uiÅ¿t in Buff know, that it is not only Å¿o, but is alÅ¿o a promiÅ¿Å¿ory Oath made to God: and therefore he is as well a party, as a witneÅ¿Å¿e to it. ObÅ¿erve here, a high point of inÅ¿olency. An interpretation put upon the Parliaments Covenant, by men that (for the moÅ¿t part) refuÅ¿e to take the Covenant.

Let not the Independent Members pleaÅ¿e themÅ¿elves in Å¿eeing the Presbyterians overthrowne, Å¿ince their turn is like to be next:4 ConÅ¿ideration. what malice and deÅ¿igne now lyes upon the Presbyterian: a covetous deÅ¿ire to Å¿hare with them in their rich gaines, will hereafter lye upon the Independents. The vaÅ¿t deÅ¿ires and expences of this Army are like a conÅ¿uming fire: He that fares beÅ¿t, Å¿hall be but the laÅ¿t fuell to it.

To conclude,5 ConÅ¿ideration. There is a deÅ¿perate party intermingled amongÅ¿t the whole MaÅ¿Å¿e of this Common-wealth, which hath perpetrated all manner of crimes from BlaÅ¿phemy, and high TreaÅ¿on, to TreÅ¿pas. They have violated all Lawes, Divine and Humane, and all Government and MagiÅ¿tracy: They have Å¿o farre cheated and abuÅ¿ed the King, and His IÅ¿Å¿ue, that like Caine, they think their Å¿innes greater then can be forgiven: they have Å¿o far injured, and cheated all the IntereÅ¿ts and People of the Land, that with Caine they thinke that every man will Å¿lay them, and deÅ¿paire of reconciliation: and therefore place all their hopes in bringing them to Å¿lavery and confuÅ¿ion. They hate all honeÅ¿t men, becauÅ¿e they
feare them as witneÅ¿Å¿es and proÅ¿ecutors to bring them to judgement hereafter. And therefore labour to ruine and extirpate them, eÅ¿pecially out of the Parliament, under the notion of the Kings Party. Wherefore (dear Country-men) eÅ¿pecially you Lords and Gentlemen of the Parliament) call to mind your duty you owe to your God, your King, your Country, your Wives, & Children; call to mind Religion, Laws and Liberties, and cry out with one voice againÅ¿t theÅ¿e innovators (as your fore-fathers did long Å¿ince in a Parliament) Nolumus Leges Angliae mutare; we will not change our good Laws. Remember your Oathes of Allegeance, Supremacy, Nationall Covenant, & ProteÅ¿tation, for which your Å¿ouls are morgaged to a juÅ¿t and Å¿evere Creditor. And learne to fear God, and not Man. We owe a death to God and Nature, and muÅ¿t aÅ¿Å¿uredly pay this debt: why not now before we taÅ¿te of miÅ¿ery and Å¿lavery? why not in an honourable defence of our Country, rather then in a baÅ¿e deÅ¿ertion of it? He that feares death, dies as Å¿oone as he that contemnes death; and no man is worthy of life, but he that Å¿cornes life, when his Country Å¿tands in need of it.

q.l: Ingens crede nefas animam praeferre pudori:
Et propter vitam, vivendi perdere cauÅ¿as.
Mors & fugacem perÅ¿equitur virum, nec parcit

div.p: Death Å¿trikes a coward in the back, as Å¿oone as a valiant man in the face.

Good God, who broughteÅ¿t all things out of Chaos into light, giving them order, forme, and beauty: Å¿uffer not the Nimrods of our times to reduce all things back againe into Chaos. Suffer them not to pull downe Sion, and build up Babel. Oh heavenly Daedalus, lend us thy Clue, to lead us out of this Labyrinth.
The Å¿umme of all theÅ¿e ObÅ¿ervations is this:
In the RemonÅ¿trance, 20 Novemb. 1648. They indeavour to Å¿ubvert the King, His PoÅ¿terity and the Kingdome.

In the 2, 3, and 4. Article of their Impeachment againÅ¿t the 11. Members. They profeÅ¿Å¿e themÅ¿elves diÅ¿obliged from any farther engagement in the Parliaments Å¿ervice: and have and doe act according to this profeÅ¿Å¿ion.
Quaere. Who theÅ¿e men Å¿erve and what judgement the law gives upon them?

div.head: PROLEGOMENA, OR, Selected ObÅ¿ervations, explaining the generall drift of the RemonÅ¿trance; and therfore Å¿et apart by themÅ¿elves.
div.p: MAjor White Å¿aid in the Councell of the Army at Putney, That Å¿hortly there Å¿hould be no viÅ¿ible Authority left in the Kingdome but the power of the Sword. Though this was then in deÅ¿igne, yet becauÅ¿e he vented it unÅ¿eaÅ¿onably, before it was ripe for practiÅ¿e, he was expelled the Army; but Å¿oon taken in again, they being unwilling to loÅ¿e a man of their owne principles.

9. March. The Engagement of the fugitive Members [to live & die with the Army] was Å¿ent from the Lords to be approved by the Commons. Whereupon, DerbyhouÅ¿e Projects, p. 7. (written by an Officer of the Army) Å¿aith, This was done to trie the temper of the HouÅ¿e, and if they had not approved it, they reÅ¿olved to flie to their Arms and make a New Charge againÅ¿t their OppoÅ¿ers; for they acknowledge amongst themÅ¿elves, That they rule by Power onely, and that the HouÅ¿e of Commons is no longer theirs then they over-awe them; and that they feare the Criticall day will come, which will diÅ¿cover the Parliament to be no longer theirs, then while they have a force upon it.

ObÅ¿erve, that upon theÅ¿e grounds the preÅ¿ent deÅ¿igne of this RemonÅ¿trance is, To make a new Charge, and diÅ¿Å¿olve this Parliament, and to make a new Parliament meerly popular, without King, or Lords; conÅ¿iÅ¿ting only of a RepreÅ¿entative of the People, of their owne chuÅ¿ing; for, the Army acknowledgeth none but themÅ¿elves and their Faction, to be the People: all other men are but Amalekites, or the Å¿eed of the curÅ¿ed, to be rooted out, that themÅ¿elves the Å¿eed of the Godly, the Faithfull onely may inherit this good Land. And this New Parliament Å¿hall be accountable to the People, that is, to the Army. Compare the RemonÅ¿tr: and the Declaration of the Army following it. So we Å¿hall be govern'd arbitrarily by a Popular Parliament protected and overruled by a Å¿tanding Army: the Lawes (which depend wholly upon the Authority of the Crowne, for their defence, interpretation, and execution) being firÅ¿t plucked up by the roots: in the pulling downe of Monarchy, look about you EngliÅ¿hmen; you have fought for Religion, Lawes, and Liberties, untill you are cheated of them all.
